article.description:
Julius Page scored 16 points and Ontario Lett added 15 as the
seventh-ranked Panthers clinched a first-round bye in the Big
East Conference tournament with an 86-54 rout of Seton Hall.
article.headline: Pittsburgh (16-0) perfect at home, earns first-round bye
article.linkText: Pittsburgh ends Hall's 9-game streak, secures Big East bye
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Just as it did a year ago, Pitt is playing its best when the tournaments are arriving. There's one difference: This time, the Panthers won't be coming back to Pittsburgh. The seventh-ranked Panthers opened up a big early lead behind some unusually strong outside shooting and got 16 points from Julius Page to end Seton Hall's nine-game winning streak, 86-54 Wednesday night. Pitt (22-4, 12-3 Big East) wrapped up a 16-0 home-court record in its first season in the Petersen Events Center and secured a first-round bye in the Big East tournament. "I think we're peaking,'' point guard Brandin Knight said after his final game in Pittsburgh. "That's what you want going with the postseason almost here. But the Big East is going to be wide open. It's going to be a tossup.'' Pitt and Syracuse are tied for first in the conference's West Division with one game each to play on Sunday, Pitt against Villanova and Syracuse against Rutgers. If they remain tied, Syracuse will be the top seed based on a better division record. No Big East team has won the tournament without the bye. Pitt has reached the finals the last two years, losing to Boston College in 2001 and Connecticut last year. "We wanted that bye,'' Page said. "We definitely didn't want to have to play that first game.'' Pitt went 29-6 while reaching the NCAA round of 16 last year, when it played its first two NCAA Tournament games at Mellon Arena. This time, Pitt can play no closer to home in the first round than Indianapolis, Boston or Nashville. "I wish we were going back to Mellon Arena,'' coach Ben Howland said. That's why the postgame sendoff from the enthusiastic crowd of 12,508 was especially emotional, with Howland hugging Knight, a third-team All-America last season. Howland pulled Knight and fellow seniors Donatas Zavackas and Ontario Lett individually so each could get a long ovation, with Knight the last to go out. With the three seniors in the lineup, Pitt is 51-10 the last two seasons and 83-39 overall. The Panthers are 31-1 at home the last two seasons and, counting the two NCAA games, 33-1 in Pittsburgh. "They're a good team and they came ready to play,'' Seton Hall coach Louis Orr said. Seton Hall (16-10, 10-5) still had a chance to win the West Division and earn a top seed if it won, but the Pirates never got back in the game after Pitt went on a 17-2 run to open a 23-10 lead. With Page and Zavackas hitting from the outside, Pitt shot 60.7 percent in each half against a defense that allowed no team to shoot better than 45.2 percent during its winning streak. The Panthers normally rely on their inside strength and depth to pull away, but Page had 13 points in the first half and Zavackas was 3-of-3 on 3-pointers. Pitt finished 7-of-10 from beyond the arc. Lett scored 15 points, while Carl Krauser added 13 and Zavackas and Jaron Brown each had 11. Knight, who will finish with more career victories than any player in Pitt history, didn't score until 12:27 remaining, but it hardly mattered. He ended the night with eight points, six rebounds and 10 assists, leaving him four assists from breaking Sean Miller's school career record. Seton Hall committed 12 turnovers in the first half and 21 overall, and thus couldn't get any closer than 16 even going on a 10-0 run midway through the second half. Andre Barrett and John Allen each had 11 points for the Pirates, who shot 38.9 percent. "A lot of those turnovers led to easy baskets, too,'' Howland said. For one night, the Pirates looked like the team that started 8-9 and lost to Manhattan before going on a winning streak that gave them a chance to land an NCAA Tournament berth. "When you lose by 30, that's enough,'' Orr said. "The team and I were embarrassed by this loss.'' It was just as Knight predicted following Pitt's 73-61 loss at Seton Hall on Feb. 15. Then, Knight told forward Marcus Toney-El, his high school teammate at Seton Hall Prep, that Pitt would remember the loss when the Pirates came to Pittsburgh. "We came out knowing this team could beat us,'' Page said.
